Preview: Japanese inflation due at 23:30GMT
content:
Nomura: We expect the January all-Japan core CPI (ex-fresh food) to rise 0.8% y-o-y, 0.1pp lower than the December reading. As the boost from energy prices weakens, we look for inflation to ease back temporarily. We expect the January all-Japan core core CPI (ex-energy and food, except alcoholic beverages) to rise 0.1% y-o-y, unchanged from December. Finally, we forecast all-Japan CPI inflation excluding fresh food and energy (the BOJ's preferred measure of core core inflation) to have risen by 0.3% y-o-y in January, again unchanged from December."

Barclays: We estimate that nationwide core inflation (y/y) eased to 0.8% in January. We look for core CPI inflation to hold around 0.8- 0.9% y/y through June, then strengthen to above 1% y/y in Q3, marking the peak for 2018.

Daiwa: Higher food prices seem likely to have lifted headline inflation in January. But while the PMIs hinted at additional pressures, the BoJ’s forecast core CPI will do well to match December’s 0.9%Y/Y pace as last January’s rare 0.2%M/M increase will roll out of the calculation.

FOREX: DXY -0.25% heading into APAC trade

The buck was soft with the DXY falling around 0.25% heading into Asia trade, particularly losing ground against the JPY, which remained beneath the 107 handle through most of US trade. There wasn’t any new narrative for today’s price action, though some had suggested that the greenback was back to following Treasury yields, though some analysts – pointing to correlation studies – suggest that this line of reasoning could be flimsy. Nevertheless, the dollar losing impetus following yesterday’s hawkish Fed allowed EUR to move back above 1.23, helped along by the ECB’s latest meeting minutes which stated that the central bank was unlikely to change its forward guidance was premature in January, though could be revised at upcoming meetings; elsewhere, the central bank was upbeat on the economy and inflation. The pound couldn’t reclaim the 1.40 despite the USD weakeness, with UK PM May in meetings with her cabinet to thrash out progress relating to Brexit. Commodity FX took its cue from crude/metals (gold did manage to regain the 1330 handle), while EMFX was mixed/slightly lower against the buck, though MXN was higher after the Banxico’s latest meeting minutes.

WTI futures settled higher on Thursday after EIA data showed a surprise build – in line with what was signalled by the API data released on Wednesday; however, the draw was deeper than the API data suggested. Also of comfort to crude will have been the slight dip in US production in the week, while Cushing inventories also printed a draw. The crude complex was also helped by a weaker dollar, with the DXY -0.25% at the crude settlement. MARKET RECAP

EQUITIES: SPX +0.1% at 2704, DJI +0.7% at 24961, NDX +0.4% at 6762

Top sectors: Energy +0.9%, Materials +0.6%, Industrials +0.4%

Bottom sectors: Financials -0.6%, Healthcare -0.25% Tech -0.16%

The EMINI S&P 500 March 2018 contract was jittery; in early trade, investors were content to shrug-off the notion of a more aggressive Fed potentially withdrawing stimulus more rapidly than anticipated – certainly more rapidly than the central bank had forecast in its December projections. There was no new narrative for today’s price action; once again, traders seem to be contending with the Fed at a time when some have been complaining about frothy valuations (for some time, it should be noted). There may have been some positioning-related elements keeping the bid in stocks: analysts at JPMorgan argued that their equity models suggest that systematic selling of US equities has significantly eased, and volatility-targeting strategies might now be building longs; the bank also said that next week’s month-end is likely to see substantial buying from fixed-weight allocators, meaning that equity flows could be “a headwind for any near-term bearish bias.” The EMINI managed to print highs just above 2730 in afternoon trade before running out of steam, and in late trade, the March 2018 contract dropped to re-test the 2700 level, and that level was breached heading into the close.

 

TREASURIES: US T-Note futures settle 7 ticks higher at 120-12+

Treasury yields were a touch lower, and major curve spreads were mixed, on a day where the US Treasury’s $258bln of supply was complete (including bills), and a hefty slate of corporate supply, which saw heavy issuance in the 5-, 10- and 30-year buckets. As that supply was launching in afternoon trade, there was some pressure on the Tplex, though the curve remained in positive territory.

The US Treasury completed its supply with a lacklustre sale of 7-year notes on Thursday. The auction saw a tail of 0.7bps, cover was the lowest since November, and direct bidders took down their largest share since September. There was a little encouragement in the internals, after indirect participation didn’t mirror what we saw out of the 2s and 5s auction this week, where it was notably high. Treasury prices were little changed following the sale.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US Treasury to auction USD 29BLN 7-Year notes at 1300 ET/1800 GMT
content:
THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The US Treasury is selling a total of USD 92bln in 2- (USD 28bln, Tues), 5- (USD 35bln, Weds) and 7-year (USD 29bln, Thurs) notes this week, as well as USD 15bln of 2-year FRNs. Next week sees approximately USD 107bln of cash flows which includes around USD 100bln in redemptions.

This set of auctions marks the first of 2-, 5- and 7-year auctions since the US Treasury announced they would be increasing the amount offered in January to help fund the anticipated growth in borrowing stemming from the Trump administration’s tax reform and spending package.

2-YR AUCTION REVIEW: Tuesday’s auction of 2s was soft, with the high yield coming in around WI levels (stops-through 0.1bps), and cover was softer than recent averages (2.72x vs six-action average of 2.83x). Additionally, dealer takedown was high (40.3% vs six-auction average of 38.1%), and indirect participation slipped versus both the previous auction and recent averages. Some had expected a better result, given concession and short positioning going into the auction. There was little market reaction.

5-YR AUCTION REVIEW: The US Treasury auctioned $35bln in new 5-year notes, which came in on the screws, with the yield highest since December 2009, while cover was slightly below recent averages. Analysts have pointed out that there were similarities to Tuesday’s auction of 2s (which stopped-through by 0.1bps), in that dealer participation was higher than recent averages, while indirect participation was lower. The sale came ahead of the FOMC’s January meeting minutes, and as such, there was limited price action in wake of the auction (again, similar to Tuesday’s auction).

7-YR AUCTION PREVIEW: The last 7-year auction saw the highest stop-out since 2011, with dealer participation notably low. The latest data shows dealers are net long in the 6-year to 7-year sector to the tune of USD 5.1bln (w/e 7 Feb). Analysts note that the current 7-year note trades fair on asset-swap against older 7s versus the previous auction cycle, while also trading fair on the curve versus 5s and 10s.  “A cheaper outright level, with the current 7-year note yield above the 7-year auctions stop-out rate since March 2011, is a positive for the upcoming auction along with the month-end extension demand,” Societe Generale writes. Negatives for the auction include the higher issuance sizes announced by the US Treasury at the recent quarterly refunding – and that supply comes amid a hefty slate of both sovereign and corporate supply this week.

FX Wrap: Initial USD gains prove to be short-lived as the DXY fails to hold onto the 90.00 handle
content: The DXY started the EU session on the front-foot as participants digested the fall-out of yesterday’s  hawkish FOMC minutes. However, a downtick in US yields eventually dragged the DXY into negative territory and below the 90.00 handle in the latter stages of play, subsequently knocking USD/JPY back below 107.00 after heavy supply at and just ahead of 108.00 capped the pair overnight. Elsewhere, Eur/Usd initially lost grip of the 1.2300 handle and looked set to be unable reclaim the psychological level, particularly in the context of weaker than expected German Ifo survey. However, the broader USD trend came to the aid of the pair in the aftermath of post-ECB minutes choppy price action after the account revealed some viewed changes in communication as premature and others expressed a preference for dropping the Bank’s easing bias. Today was a relatively contained session for GBP (EUR/GBP a more suitable barometer given the USD move), after lacklustre GDP data failed to dent the pair with markets awaiting any announcements from the UK government’s ‘away day’; GBP/USD held  above chart support seen around 1.3830. Elsewhere, Usd/Cad failed to make a sustained penetration of solid resistance between 1.2715-20. Nzd/Usd held above 0.7300 ahead of NZ Q4 retail sales overnight (consensus 1.4% q/q vs 0.2% previously, but forecast range wide at 0.6%-2% so plenty of scope for a surprise either side). Aud/Usd was also lifted in the latter half of the session by the softer USD after straddling 0.7800.

subject: Bunds: belated and mild bid post-ECB minutes
content: In stark contrast to the moves in US Treasuries after FOMC minutes, Bunds have edged higher after the ECB confirmed that January was too early to seriously consider altering guidance. There was some initial reservation on the revelation that some GC members favoured removing the easing bias, but again this is not really a surprise given well known more hawkish policy setters. The 10 year German benchmark has climbed to 158.68 and back towards the 158.75 Eurex peak, but still short of yesterday’s session best ahead of a busy US agenda. Meanwhile, Gilts continue to languish and have retreated below par after a knee-jerk bounce on the UK GDP data. More action in FX where the Usd is firming up again, but still underperforming the safe-haven Jpy.

subject: ECB MINUTES: Changes in communication are premature, policymakers said in January
content:
- Communication stance could be revisited at upcoming meetings in early part of 2018
- Some expressed preference for dropping easing bias
- ECB says policy will evolve to avoid abrupt, disorderly adjustments
- Policymakers in broad agreement regarding EUR's volatility
- ECB is increasingly confident about inflation, but patience is required
- Pace of expansion could strengthen, growth is robust
reaction_details: In an immediate reaction to the comment regarding it being premature to readjust language, EUR/USD saw a modest dip lower before paring losses after it was revealed that some expressed a preference for dropping their easing bias
analysis_details:
Pictet's ECB-watcher Frederik Ducrozet says the minutes were marginally more hawkish (citing the line 'underlying measures of inflation had so far remained stable despite the appreciation of the exchange rate'). But Ducrozet says the minutes were no surprise, adding that the line 'some members expressed a preference for dropping the easing bias regarding the APP' suggests that this will be decided in March, however, Ducrozet notes this is a close call.

UBS says the central bank has acknowledged the improvement in the economy, but it is too early to say whether it will be sustained, so the central bank is moving cautiously towards the exit, as the market expects. On FX, UBS notes that the minutes show the ECB expressing confusion as to why the USD is so weak. Meanwhile, there is a sense of optimism on inflation, with the central bank taking comfort from underlying measures remaining stable despite the recent appreciation of the euro. "The tone throughout is cautiously optimistic, but not yet at a point where policy or communication can be altered."

PREVIEW: ECB January Minutes due to be released Thursday 22nd February at 1230GMT/0630CST
content:
PLEASE CLICK HERE FOR THE FULL REPORT

This week sees the release of the ECB’s account of the January meeting which saw the central bank refrain from providing
much of a blueprint as to how they intend to unwind their current stimulus programme after its current end-date of September.
During his press conference, Draghi gave little away in terms of what discussions had taken place.

Despite this, markets will be on the look-out for any hints of timing for the ECB to alter their language around forward guidance;
something that was touted to happen in the early stages of this year as revealed by the December minutes. Any clarity around this
issue could set up market expectations for the ECB’s March meeting which could be decisive for the ECB to outline their plans for
2018. In terms of recent rhetoric from the ECB, Vasiliauskas has stated that it is appropriate to rephrase ECB’s guidance to focus
on all instruments, not just bonds and that ECB’s QE should be tapered and not be ended suddenly

Additionally, focus at the previous conference fell on the ECB’s assessment of recent FX volatility, something that at the time
Draghi described as a source of uncertainty. This was then followed up by source reports suggesting that rate setters are split on
their views regarding the timing of their next move given the recent EUR move, therefore any clarity on this issue will be
welcomed by the market albeit the recent extension of USD weakness may leave any stated views slightly out-of-date.

As ever with the ECB minutes, they come out four weeks after the initial meeting and as such are often perceived as slightly out-ofdate
but (as was the case with the previous minutes release), still have the propensity to move the market if they are at odds with
what was discussed during Draghi’s press conference.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European equities (-1%) have kicked the session off on the back-foot as European participants digest the fall-out of yesterdays FOMC minutes
content:
22nd February 2018

  • European equities (-1%) have kicked the session off on the back-foot as European participants digest the fall-out of yesterday’s FOMC minutes
  • The DXY has nailed 90.000 with the aid of hawkish FOMC minutes, but Usd/Jpy continues to buck the broader trend amidst the ongoing global stock market retracement
  • Looking ahead, highlights ECB minutes, US weekly jobs, DoEs and a slew of speakers

ASIA

Asian markets trading broadly in the red with exception of the Shanghai Comp (+2.2%) which outperforms are participants plays catch up from their elongated break. The prospect of ‘further’ gradual rate hikes as noted in the most recent FOMC minutes boosted speculation that 4 rate hikes could be on the table particularly that these minutes were before the strong wage data in the most recent NFP and inflation data last week, which had subsequently pushed bond yields higher with the US 10yr yield hitting 2.95%, while equities slumped late in the US session. This transpired in Asia, with the Nikkei (-1.1%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) seeing losses of over 1%, while ASX 200 (+0.1%) saw initial 0.4% gains trimmed, with price action in Australia largely dictated by the slew of earnings. In credit markets, the belly of the curve underperformed, with JGB 10yr yields tracking UST yields higher, while a firm 20yr JGB auction supported longer dated debt.

Japan PM Abe Adviser Hamada says the BoJ should consider buying foreign bonds. (Newswires)

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3530 (Prev. 6.3428). (Newswires)

North Korea to have official visit to the South on February 25th with President Moon meeting delegation. (Yonhap)

EU/UK/US

According to a report in Telegraph, senior ministers stated that the cabinet had not agreed to PM May's negotiating strategy for the transition period after Brexit before it was sent to the EU. (Telegraph)

EU Official doubts the Brexit transition will hit the March deadline. (Newswires)

UK GDP 2nd Release QQ (Q4) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

UK GDP 2nd Release YY (Q4) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%)

German Ifo Business Climate (Feb) 115.4 vs. Exp. 117.0 (Prev. 117.6)

German Ifo Expectations (Feb) 105.4 vs. Exp. 107.9 (Prev. 108.4 Rev. 108.3)

CENTAL BANKS

Fed's Quarles states that gradual interest rate increases are appropriate, adding that soft inflation likely transitory and is not a cause for great concern. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari stress the need to wait & see on inflation, adds that US economy is doing very well and is surprised at confidence due to tax cut. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities (-1%) have kicked the session off on the back-foot as European participants digest the fall-out of yesterday’s more hawkish than anticipated FOMC minutes which saw rate-setters take a confident view on the growth and inflation outlook. In terms of sector specific moves, material names modestly lag their peers following price action in the complex as well as a disappointing earnings update from Anglo American (-4%) which has sent their shares near the bottom of the FSTE 100; with the index also hampered by lacklustre earnings from the likes of British American Tobacco (-4.6%), Barratt Developments (-4.0%) and BAE systems. However, losses for UK stocks have been capped by a well-received earnings report from Barclays (+5.1%) which allied with upside in AXA shares (+1.2%) post-earnings has also supported the financial sector.

FX

The DXY has nailed 90.000 with the aid of hawkish FOMC minutes, but Usd/Jpy continues to buck the broader trend amidst the ongoing global stock market retracement and heightened volatility. Flow-wise, heavy supply at and just ahead of 108.00 is still capping the pair, while 108.02 represents Fib resistance and the headline looks increasingly toppy given lower peaks since the recent 107.90 high. Hence, the broader Dollar and index is struggling to maintain gains and mount a challenge of the next upside technical objective at 90.886 despite reclaiming more lost ground vs other G10 rivals. Eur/Usd has lost grip of the 1.2300 handle and could see more downside on the back of a significantly weaker than expected German Ifo survey, especially as the technical picture also looks bearish below its 1.2319 Fib level and with little in the way of support until 1.2206. Cable is testing bids under 1.3900 amidst latest Brexit-related UK political accusations aimed at PM May, but holding above chart support seen around 1.3830. As per the single currency, Sterling may be prone to further losses in wake of a data miss as UK Q4 GDP was downgraded on zero business investment during the quarter (again likely as a result of Brexit). Elsewhere, Usd/majors fairly flat as the DXY hovers just above the 90.000 level.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have extended post-German Ifo survey gains, and maintained outperformance vs Gilts in the process even though UK debt has been boosted by an unexpected downward revision to Q4 growth (and no business investment whatsoever). The 10 year German benchmark has been up to 158.75 (+24 ticks), but just shy of major resistance on some daily charts at 158.78 and Wednesday’s 158.85 intraday Eurex peak, while its Liffe equivalent has rebounded to 121.68 (+7 ticks vs -32 ticks at worst), with small index-linked supply next on the domestic agenda ahead of the CBI’s retail survey. Elsewhere, USTs continue to regain losses as well amidst the weaker equity tone and on some consolidation after the Fed minutes fall-out, but futures remain close to recent lows and yields near latest highs with the curve still flatter in the run up to the 7 year auction.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude trade lower albeit off worst levels after falling victim to the firmer USD despite last night’s unexpected draw in the API report. As a reminder, due to the President’s Day Holiday on Monday the weekly DoE report will be released today at the rescheduled time of 1600GMT. In metals markets, gold prices have also been hampered by the firmer USD, however, the move to the downside has perhaps been contained due to the price action seen in EU stocks this morning. Elsewhere, steel prices were seen lower during Asia-Pac trade as Chinese participants slowly returned from holiday, with a bulk of the market not expected to fully return until next week.

UK STIRs rattled, Gilts to gap down ahead of 2nd UK GDP read
content: A marked downturn in Short Sterling futures with the strip as much as 3 ticks below Wednesday’s settlement levels, mainly on the back of the latest Fed minutes, but also after BoE testimony underscored expectations for further policy normalisation somewhat sooner and more than previously envisaged. UK debt is also heading for a weaker Liffe open in line with negative leads from fixed counterparts and expected to decline around ¼ point from yesterday’s 121.61 close, if not a tad more, although Bunds continue to chip away at losses and just ticked up to 158.37 (-14 ticks vs -33 ticks in very early Eurex trade). Ahead, the first revision to Q4 GDP is forecast to confirm initial readings, while the consensus for CBI trades looks for a modest uptick. Supply also on tap via the DMO’s Gbp950 mn 2036 linker that should be relatively well received.

subject: Barclays on todays UK I/L supply:
content:
In the UK, the DMO reopens the IL36 via a GBP 950mln notional auction today, equivalent to a cash size just shy of GBP 1.4bln and GBP 2.6mln/bp of risk.

Barclays suspect the market is short of this sector of the index-linked gilt curve, given that most DMO consultation meeting minutes have referenced linker demand shifting to the 20-30y sector from the very long end of the curve.

Accordingly, Barclays expect the auction process itself to go relatively smoothly.

However, linker auctions have generally shown a pattern of late whereby the market and bond perform solidly into auctions and then lag afterward.

subject: DAILY BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: Supply today comes from the UK and US
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: UK GBP 0.95bln 0.125% I/L 2036 Gilt Auction

IFR:

- The auction sees the breakeven a little firmer than the last tap as the market is still short of inflation in light of the increased CPI expectations

- Don’t expect too much in the way of fireworks and the modest size should deliver a drama free result

In terms of historical data:

Prev. b/c 2.34x and real yield -1.65%

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: US Treasury to auction USD 29BLN 7-Year notes at 1300 ET/1800 GMT on 22 February 2018

THIS WEEK’S SUPPLY: The US Treasury is selling a total of USD 92bln in 2- (USD 28bln, Tues), 5- (USD 35bln, Weds) and 7-year (USD 29bln, Thurs) notes this week, as well as USD 15bln of 2-year FRNs. Next week sees approximately USD 107bln of cash flows which includes around USD 100bln in redemptions.

This set of auctions marks the first of 2-, 5- and 7-year auctions since the US Treasury announced they would be increasing the amount offered in January to help fund the anticipated growth in borrowing stemming from the Trump administration’s tax reform and spending package.

2-YR AUCTION REVIEW: Tuesday’s auction of 2s was soft, with the high yield coming in around WI levels (stops-through 0.1bps), and cover was softer than recent averages (2.72x vs six-action average of 2.83x). Additionally, dealer takedown was high (40.3% vs six-auction average of 38.1%), and indirect participation slipped versus both the previous auction and recent averages. Some had expected a better result, given concession and short positioning going into the auction. There was little market reaction.

5-YR AUCTION REVIEW: The US Treasury auctioned $35bln in new 5-year notes, which came in on the screws, with the yield highest since December 2009, while cover was slightly below recent averages. Analysts have pointed out that there were similarities to Tuesday’s auction of 2s (which stopped-through by 0.1bps), in that dealer participation was higher than recent averages, while indirect participation was lower. The sale came ahead of the FOMC’s January meeting minutes, and as such, there was limited price action in wake of the auction (again, similar to Tuesday’s auction).

7-YR AUCTION PREVIEW: The last 7-year auction saw the highest stop-out since 2011, with dealer participation notably low. The latest data shows dealers are net long in the 6-year to 7-year sector to the tune of USD 5.1bln (w/e 7 Feb). Analysts note that the current 7-year note trades fair on asset-swap against older 7s versus the previous auction cycle, while also trading fair on the curve versus 5s and 10s.  “A cheaper outright level, with the current 7-year note yield above the 7-year auctions stop-out rate since March 2011, is a positive for the upcoming auction along with the month-end extension demand,” Societe Generale writes. Negatives for the auction include the higher issuance sizes announced by the US Treasury at the recent quarterly refunding – and that supply comes amid a hefty slate of both sovereign and corporate supply this week.

subject: Bunds: taking heed of hawkish Fed minutes
content: A further retreat and rejection of yesterday’s highs approaching the 159.00 level in response to the more upbeat and hawkish (overall) FOMC minutes that saw US Treasuries reverse initial gains and yield declines amidst more bear-flattening of the curve. The core Eurozone bond opened at 158.24 vs Wednesday’s 158.51 Eurex close and posted an early 158.18 low before finding some underlying bids and bouncing to 158.34 – likely eyeing weaker EU stock futures following a late Wall Street sell-off and losses across the bulk of Asia-Pac bourses overnight. Ahead, Germany’s Ifo survey in focus, but the regional spotlight falls on the ECB and minutes from the January policy meeting. On the supply front, the final leg of this week’s mega US issuance arrives in the form of Usd29 bn 7 year notes that normally draws decent foreign demand and comes with a bigger concession given the latest rise in rates across the curve. However, indirect bidders have been reticent so far and another set of weak results could be the precursor for another leg higher.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: FOMC minutes showed signs of confidence on inflation and the growth outlook; weighed on stocks, supported USD
content:
• FOMC minutes showed signs of confidence on inflation and the growth outlook; weighed on stocks, supported USD
  • Senior ministers stated that the cabinet had not agreed to PM May's negotiating strategy before it was sent to the EU
  • Looking ahead, highlights German IFO, UK GDP, ECB minutes, US weekly jobs, DoEs and a slew of speakers

FOMC MEETING MINUTES: Confident on inflation and the growth outlook

  • The FOMC’s meeting minutes noted that the recent strengthening of US economy has increased the likelihood of further gradual rate hikes, with most voters saying that recent data supported view that inflation will rise in 2018, and stabilise around the 2% target in the mediumterm
  • A couple, however,  were concerned about the inflation outlook, and saw an appreciable risk that inflation will lag target (which many traders were attributing to the immediate dovish market response).
  • With that said, most were of the opinion that recent data points to a modestly stronger economic outlook than was forecast in December, and voting members generally judged risks as roughly balanced; in fact, several saw the potential for increased upside risks to the nearterm economic outlook.
  • The market was pricing a March hike with nearcertainty (93.5% implied probability); implied probability of three FOMC hikes in 2018 is up to 66.6% vs 60.6% on Tuesday, while the probability of four hikes rose to 29.6% vs 25% on Tuesday.

NOTE: These meeting minutes are from the FOMC meeting in January that preceded the stronger NFP wage data, firm inflation data, and the volatility in financial markets

ASIA

Asian markets trading broadly in the red with exception of the Shanghai Comp (+2.1%) which outperforms are participants plays catch up from their elongated break. The prospect of ‘further’ gradual rate hikes as noted in the most recent FOMC minutes boosted speculation that 4 rate hikes could be on the table particularly that these minutes were before the strong wage data in the most recent NFP and inflation data last week, which had subsequently pushed bond yields higher with the US 10yr yield hitting 2.95%, while equities slumped late in the US session. This transpired in Asia, with the Nikkei (-1.2%) and Hang Seng (-1%) seeing losses of over 1%, while ASX 200 (+0.1%) saw initial 0.4% gains trimmed, with price action in Australia largely dictated by the slew of earnings. In credit markets, the belly of the curve underperformed, with JGB 10yr yields tracking UST yields higher, while a firm 20yr JGB auction supported longer dated debt.

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3530 (Prev. 6.3428). (Newswires)

UK/EU

According to a report in Telegraph, senior ministers stated that the cabinet had not agreed to PM May's negotiating strategy for the transition period after Brexit before it was sent to the EU. (Telegraph)

FX

Across FX markets, the USD index hovers back 90.00 following the hawkish FOMC meeting minutes, while throughout the Asian session JPY is notably firmer against its counterpart amid the risk off tone, which has seen the JPY trading at session highs. Elsewhere, antipodeans are on the back foot with the AUD weakening through the 0.78 handle vs the greenback. AU 10yr yield now trading at a 6bps discount to US 10yr yields, while the currency has also been pressured from the softness in commodity markets.

COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures failed to be supported by the surprise drawdown in last nights API crude report, with WTI trading with losses of around 1%. Additionally, moves to the downside had been exacerbated after stops had been tripped at USD 61.05, which saw WTI hit a low of USD 60.75 and as such now remains below the USD 61.00/bbl mark. Precious metals had a relatively quiet session as gold prices languished around yesterday’s lows.

US

TREASURIES: US T-Note Futures settle 9 ticks lower at 120-06+

The US Treasury auctioned $35bln in new 5-year notes, which came in on the screws, with the yield highest since December 2009, while cover was slightly below recent averages. Analysts have pointed out that there were similarities to Tuesday’s auction of 2s (which stopped-through by 0.1bps), in that dealer participation was higher than recent averages, while indirect participation was lower. The sale came ahead of the FOMC’s January meeting minutes, and as such, there was limited price action in wake of the auction (again, similar to yesterday’s auction).

The immediate reaction to the FOMC’s meeting minutes was dovish, albeit very muted. However, as the details were digested, the tplex saw selling pressure, with T-Note futures finding fresh session lows and yields for 10s and 30s rising to YTD highs. At settlement, the curve had bear steepened, and major curve spreads had widened (5s30s was particularly noticeable rising c.3bps).
